Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

ALLEGATION:
Resident A has a broken finger reportedly due to putting a water bottle in the frame
of her bedroom door. This is the agency's second incident of a youth getting a
broken finger.
INVESTIGATION:
I reviewed the complaint allegation on 8/17/2020 and spoke with Consultant 2 on
8/18/2020. This matter initially came to the department’s attention due to Resident A
being at Hurley hospital with a broken finger and her parent’s refusal to give surgical
consent. Consultant 2 informed me that the agency emailed her about Resident A’s
2

injury. The agency reported Resident A was placing a water bottle in the doorframe
hinge to prevent the door from closing and the door shut on her thumb. Additionally,
that Resident A reported staff was not involved in shutting the door.
On 8/18/2020 I spoke with Resident A’s Department of Health and Human Services
Foster Care Worker (DHHS-FCW). She was aware of the incident. The agency
contacted her on Saturday (8/15/2020). The agency informed her Resident A was
destroying her room and got her finger caught in the door when she tried to close it.
The DHHS-FCW could not recall if a water bottle were mentioned. The DHHS-FCW
called the facility to speak with Resident A. Resident A refused to speak with her.
The DHHS-FCW reported Resident A has many emotional issues and her
behavioral outbursts are not unusual. She reported getting numerous incident
reports on Resident A and 99% of them are due to physical aggression by Resident
A (i.e. kicking or assaulting staff, her twin sister, and other residents). She said,
Resident A has been at the facility since about 10/23/2019. The agency has now,
requested Resident A’s removal; and a targeted 30-day replacement date is
pending.
On 8/20/2020, during an on-site visit, I spoke with Administrator 0. She reported
Resident A has a broken thumb. Resident A was seen a Hurley hospital the day of
the incident on 8/15/2020. Resident needs surgery on her thumb and has a medical
follow up on 8/31/2020. Administrator 0 reported there was no video footage of the
incident due to the angle of the camera.
On 8/20/2020 during an on-site visit I interviewed Staff 1. Staff 1 was thought to
have information about the incident. Staff 1 is a Vemco unit staff. She was not
present at the time of the incident but was present when Resident A returned from
the hospital. Resident A told her what happened. Resident A reported she was
trying to squirt Staff 3 with water. Resident A said she had put a water bottle in the
door, slammed the door and it slammed her hand. Resident A thought the water
would push out the bottle. Resident A did not say why Resident A wanted to do that
to Staff 3. Staff 1 speculated Resident A’s actions were due to Resident A being
mad at Staff 3. Staff 1 advised that Resident A has a habit of coming out of her
room early in the morning without permission and Staff 3 has explained to Resident
A, she (Resident A) can’t just do that. Staff 1 reported Resident A is always
slamming her door when she gets upset. A couple of weeks ago Resident A broke
her door by slamming it. She also broke her door when she was on the McDonald
unit. Staff 1 reported Resident A regularly tries to attack her peers when she
(Resident A) is upset. Resident A will apologize, only to return to the same behavior.
Resident A was moved from one unit to another due her misbehavior. Staff have
constantly spoken with Resident A about her behavior and the door slamming.
On 8/20/2020 I interviewed Staff 2 on-site. Staff 2 affirmed information in her incident
report as outline later in this report. Staff 2 reported her shift, which was on the
Johnson unit, not Resident A’s unit, ended at 8:00am. Staff 2 said, Resident A was
out of her room (before 8:00am/ before medication time, which is between 8:00am-
3

8:30am) and going back and forth between the Vemco unit and the Johnson unit.
Staff 2 said since Staff 3 was the only staff on Vemco, Staff 3 couldn’t shadow
Resident A. Staff 2 said she was able to keep an eye on Resident A. She said, the
incident happened after she got Resident A back on the Vemco unit, but she was not
present went it happened. Staff 2 was in the laundry/storage room getting a DVD
player for Resident 2. Staff 2 heard Resident A scream that her finger was broken.
When Staff 2 arrived back to the area, Staff 3 and Resident A were at Resident A’s
door. Blood was on the floor and Staff 3 was wrapping Resident A’s finger to stop
the bleeding. Staff 2 took Resident A to the medical staff (not a nurse) and called
her unit manager.
Staff 2 said, she took Resident A to Hurley hospital because there was no one else
who could take Resident A. The second Vemco staff had not arrived prior to Staff
2’s departure for the hospital. Another staff relieved Staff 2 at the hospital at
10:30am. Staff 2 said, the hospital took x-rays of Resident A’s hand. The hospital
advised Resident A needed to see the hand specialist due to Resident A’s finger
being fractured. Staff 2 said Resident A told her how the injury happened. Resident
A reported she (Resident A) was trying to throw a water bottle at Staff 3, and
Resident A’s hand got caught in the door. Resident A was throwing the bottle at Staff
3 because Staff 3 “was pissing her off”. Resident A gave no explanation of what that
meant. Staff 2 advised that Resident A has anger outbursts; and Resident A can go
from 0-10 then back in a second. She reported the staff are working to finding
Resident A’s triggers, but that’s difficult because Resident A’s triggers are constantly
changing.
On 8/20/2020 I interviewed Resident A on-site. Resident A reported she smashed
her hand in her bedroom door. She was trying to put a water bottle in the door so it
would squeeze out on Staff 3, but her hand got stuck and the door closed on her
finger. She reported, when she was holding the bottle in the door her thumb was up
near the mouth of the water bottle and she was pushing the door when Staff 3
pushed it closed. The door caught her thumb. Resident A reported, doing what she
did with the water bottle because she was upset with Staff 3. Staff 3 “was being petty
and rude about something” (Resident A could not recall what that something was)
she asked permission to do; and Staff 3 wouldn’t allow it. Resident A said, “What
happened to my finger had nothing to do with staff hurting me.” She did not know
what other staff worked with Staff 3. She said no other resident witnessed what
happened. She did not report who took her to the hospital, but said she had
surgery and got stitches at the hospital.
On 8/20/2020 I interviewed Staff 3 on-site. Staff 3 reported her/the shift was 6:00am-
2:00pm. She was the only staff on the shift. She said she was waiting for her co-
worker who never showed. She reported sometime prior to Resident A’s injury,
Resident A asked to leave her room to go to the bathroom. Resident A went to the
bathroom, returned to her room, but came out again. Resident A said she was out
of her room throwing away trash. Staff 3 instructed Resident A to return to her
bedroom, but Resident A did not. Resident A walked off the unit. Staff 3 said, she
4

couldn’t shadow behind Resident A because she (Staff 3) was the only staff on the
unit. Seven minutes later Resident A was returned to the unit by Staff 4. Staff 3
saw Staff 4 return Resident A into the unit, but Staff 3 did not talk with them about
that incident. Resident A was to sit on the bench near the unit entrance, she did so,
but got up. Resident A proceeded to her room but came out again. Staff 3
instructed Resident A to go back to her room, and Resident A asked why she (Staff
3) “have to be so petty”. Resident A didn’t go to her room. Resident A proceeded
toward the kitchen and picked up a soap bottle and threw it across the room.
Resident A appeared to be going toward a cubby that contained objects. Since
Resident A was showing signs of aggression Staff 3 said she followed policy, which
requires that she remove potential harmful items from near Resident A and Resident
A’s room. Staff 3 removed the soap bottle, two journals and a pencil and secured the
items. Resident A got mad about that and walked off the unit again. This time Staff
2 brought Resident A back to the unit. Staff 2 assisted her (Staff 3). Resident A
picked up Staff 3’s phone from a desk and threw it. Staff 2 went towards Resident A
and Resident A swung on Staff 2. Staff 3 intervened and she and Staff 2 each held
one of Resident A’s arms. Resident A was cursing and trying to hit either of them.
Then, Resident B came out his room and asked for his DVD player. Resident B was
getting upset that he couldn’t get it and Staff 2 agreed to go get it.
Staff 3 said she was standing with Resident A and Resident B who were both calm.
However, Resident A got upset and Resident A dug her nails into Staff 3’s wrist.
Staff 3 did not restrain Resident A. Staff 3 transported Resident A to Resident A’s
room by carrying Resident A. Staff 3 said she knew it wasn’t right, but she made the
“executive decision” to do what she did because he had been there almost all
morning going back and forth trying to get Resident A to go to her room. She said,
“I grabbed her under her shoulders and lifted her off the floor” and transported her to
the room. Resident A allowed her to do so; and didn’t get mad until she got Resident
A into her room. Resident A then threw Resident A’s birthday stuff out the room.
Resident A also took an Aquafina water bottle and put it in her door and swung the
open. The water bottle was in the door, so Resident A tried to throw the bottle at her
and the door swung closed. Staff 3 said her hand was never on Resident A’s door.
She was never pushing the door closed while Resident A was pushing it open. She
said the doors are heavy and they close on their own after opening and letting them
go.
Staff 3 said, she didn’t know Resident A was injured until Resident A yelled and she
went to see what was wrong. Resident A was crying and accusing staff, saying,
“look what the fuck you did”. Resident A’s finger was bleeding. Resident 3 reported
that Staff 2 returned soon thereafter and agreed to take Resident A to the nurse.
Staff 3 reported prior to the incident she and Resident A had a good relationship.
She said Resident A loves her.
Reviewed:
Staff 2’s handwritten incident report dated 8/15/2020 that indicated the incident time
as 8:00 am. It further indicated:
5

 Resident A had walked out of the unit and was running between units. Staff
told Resident A to head back to the unit and waited for Resident A to go back
into the Vemco unit.
 Staff 2 went into the Vemco unit and Resident A started to throw stuff at both
she and Staff 3. Resident A was cursing and calling them names. Resident A
refused to walk and lay on the floor. Staff held her arms to keep her from
hitting and running.
 Staff 2 went to get keys. Staff 3 transported Resident A to her room and Staff
2 opened Resident A’s door. Staff 3 said she would sit in front of the door in
an attempt to prevent Resident A from running.
 Staff 2 went to get a DVD player for another peer. While doing so Staff 2
heard Resident A yell her finger was broke and there was blood. Staff 2 took
Resident A to the medical office where the am medical staff looked at
Resident A’s right hand. The medical staff advised Resident A needed to go
the hospital. Staff 2 immediately transported Resident A to Hurley hospital.
Staff 3 handwritten incident report dated 815/2020 for an incident time of 7:20am,
which indicated information basically as reported by Staff 3 when interviewed.
Hurley Hospital After Visit Summary for Resident A for 8/15/2020-8-16/2020 that the
indicated:
 She was seen for laceration of right thumb with complication for open wound
of the finger with complications.
 She had a surgical incision.
 She was to follow up with the general surgery in two weeks.
File documentation for Resident A that indicated:
 She was placed at Whaley Children’s Center on 10/25/2019. She has a twin
sister who is also placed at the facility.
 She is a temporary court ward.
 She is diagnosed with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder. She has a history
of verbal and physical aggression toward peers and staff. She requires multiple
redirections.
 She receives individual and group therapy to assist her with anger and
interpersonal interactions.
A favorable February 2020 performance evaluations for Staff 3, which indicated:
her strongest area was child interaction and relationship building. Additionally, that she
advocates for residents and makes them her priority. She was encouraged to be mindful
of her tone with residents in all situation.
No disciplinary actions were reported documented for Staff 3.
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.158 Discipline.
(2) An institution shall prohibit all cruel and severe
discipline, including any of the following:
(a) Any type of corporal punishment inflicted in any
manner.
ANALYSIS: The findings do not support that a staff slammed Resident A’s
hand/finger in the resident’s bedroom door, or that severe
discipline was rendered.
Resident A tried to pull a prank on Staff 3. Resident A tried to
force her bedroom door onto a water filled water bottle in an
attempt to have the water squirt out on Staff 3. Resident A
thumb got smashed in the progress of the door closing, causing
the injury to her thumb.
Technical assistance
I spoke with Administrator 0 regarding safety planning pertaining
to the bedroom doors. The agency developed a safety plan
which indicated they would place slow hinges on all residents’
doors. The hinges will enable the doors to close slowly.
On 9/16/2020 the agency reported, and Consultant 2 observed
that door swing arms/hinges were placed on the residents’
bedroom doors in two of the facility’s three units. The third unit
was under renovation and had no residents.
CONCLUSION VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
7

ANALYSIS: The evidence does not support that Resident A’s injury was
caused a result of a lack of protection and supervision.
However, the facility was out of staff- to- resident ratio, as
reported in the additional findings section of this report.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS
During the investigation it was discovered the facility did not comply with their staff-
to-resident- ratio; and the staff did not use appropriate physical management to
transport the resident.
INVESTIGATION
Staff 2 and Staff 3 reported Staff 3 was alone on Vemco unit for the shift. Staff 2 said
Staff 3 was trying to get in touch with management to find out who was assigned to
work the shift with Staff 3. Staff 2 said since Staff 3 was the only staff on the Vemco
unit, Staff 3 couldn’t shadow Resident A when Resident A left the unit. Staff 2 was
from the Johnson unit; she kept an eye on Resident A. After the incident with
Resident A, Staff 2 stayed over to assist Staff 3. Staff 2 reported when she took
Resident A to the hospital, the second staff had not arrived. Staff 2 reported she was
relieved by another staff at the hospital at 10:30am.
Staff 3 reported her/the shift was 6:00am- 2:00pm. She said there was supposed to
be another staff working with her and she was waiting for that co-worker. She never
called her supervisor about getting another staff. The nurse did. The co-worker
never showed prior to the incident. The person arrived around 9:00am, after the
incident and after Resident A had left for the hospital.
Both Staff 2 and Staff 3 reported there were six residents on the unit and the
facility’s staff- to- resident ratio is 1:3. When Staff 2 took Resident A to the hospital
there were five residents on the unit with Staff 3.
Furthermore, Staff 3 reported when she was standing with Resident A and Resident
B both were calm. Then, Resident A got upset and Resident A dug her nails into her
Staff 3’s wrist. Staff 3 did not restrain Resident A. She transported Resident A to
Resident A’s room by carrying Resident A. Staff 3 said she knew it wasn’t right, but
she made the “executive decision” to do what she did because he had been there
almost all morning going back and forth with trying to get Resident A to go to her
room. She said, “I grabbed her under her shoulders and lifted her off the floor” and
transported her to the room.
Administrator 0 indicated the staffing as reported during the interviews was
correct. She said the first shift staff was late that day which was why the third shift
staff remained late to maintain ratio.
8

Administrator 0 indicated their policy did not include anything about not allowing
transports when they updated their restraint policy. Their discussion with their
consultant was a matter of whether they had a policy against it or not.
Reviewed:
Documents indicated earlier in this report.
Whaley’s Physical Intervention- Restraint Policy which:
 Indicated the crisis intervention model that Whaley Children’s Center utilizes
is the Therapeutic Crisis Intervention (TCI) model, which emphasizes verbal
de-escalation and active listening skills to diffuse crisis situations. The TCI
model does include physical restraint strategies that are utilized as the last
resort to maintain safety.
 Does not address appropriate or inappropriate transport. Nor whether a staff
use of carrying a child by picking the child up under their arms or shoulders is
to occur.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
ANALYSIS: The agency did not adhere to its 1:3 staff-to-resident ratio.
Staff 3 was supervising six residents by herself for a number of
hours prior to the incident. Staff 2 intervened to assist Staff 3
sometime prior to Resident A’s injury. Once Resident A was
taken to the hospital by Staff 2, Staff 3 was left with five
residents for a period of time.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specially addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
9

ANALYSIS: Staff 3 admitted she went under Resident A’s shoulders and
lifted Resident A off the floor and carried Resident A to Resident
A’s bedroom. She reported knowing that method of transport
was not proper but made the “executive decision” to use it.
The agency’s physical intervention policy does not
address/describe resident transport. Clear policy is needed.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the facility
current licensing status is recommended.
